questions.question: This ancient Mesopotamian code, one of the earliest known legal systems, prescribed 'an eye for an eye'.
This 11th-century Norman leader conquered England in 1066.
This 14th-century pandemic wiped out 1/3 of Europe's population.
This 18th-century queen of France famously said, 'Let them eat cake' (though likely apocryphal).
This 1969 event saw humans land on the Moon for the first time.
This 19th-century inventor of the telephone famously said, 'Mr. Watson, come here.'
This ancient wonder, located in Egypt, is the only one still standing today.
This 16th-century English monarch had six wives and founded the Church of England.
This 1912 ship, deemed 'unsinkable', sank on its maiden voyage.
This 1989 event saw the fall of a symbolic divide between East and West Germany.
questions.answer: The Fall of the Berlin Wall

questions.question: This force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun.
This gas, exhaled by humans, is absorbed by plants during photosynthesis.
This particle, discovered in 2012, is nicknamed the 'God Particle'.
This phenomenon causes the sky to appear blue during the day.
This organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'.
This chemical element has the atomic number 79 and symbol 'Au'.
This neurological condition causes temporary memory loss, often due to head trauma.
This 17th-century scientist formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation.
This medical imaging technique uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves.
This theoretical framework describes gravity as the curvature of spacetime.
This 1997 film, the highest-grossing of its time, features the line, 'I'm the king of the world!'
This singer's alter ego is 'Sasha Fierce'.
This 2012 Korean viral hit became the first YouTube video to hit 1 billion views.
This TV show's characters include Sheldon Cooper and Penny.
This 1984 film starred Arnold Schwarzenegger as a cyborg assassin.
This rapper's real name is Marshall Mathers.
This streaming service debuted 'Stranger Things' in 2016.
This 2009 film about blue aliens became the highest-grossing movie of all time.
This artist painted the 'Mona Lisa' and 'The Last Supper'.
This 1969 music festival became synonymous with the counterculture movement.
This company created the Windows operating system.
This search engine's original name was 'Backrub'.
This programming language was created by Guido van Rossum and named after a comedy troupe.
This 1997 computer defeated chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov.
This social media platform limits posts to 280 characters.
This cryptocurrency, created in 2009, was the first decentralized digital currency.
This company's CEO is Tim Cook.
This protocol is the foundation of the modern internet (hint: HTTP uses it).
This AI chatbot, released in 2022, was developed by OpenAI.
This 1969 event marked the first connection between two computers over ARPANET, the precursor to the internet.
This Shakespeare tragedy features the line, 'To be or not to be.'
This Oscar Wilde novel tells the story of a man whose portrait ages while he remains youthful.
This dystopian novel features a totalitarian regime and 'Newspeak'.
This J.K. Rowling series follows a young wizard named Harry Potter.
This F. Scott Fitzgerald novel is set in the Roaring Twenties and features Jay Gatsby.
This Herman Melville novel follows the vengeful Captain Ahab and a white whale.
This Jane Austen novel begins with the line, 'It is a truth universally acknowledged...'
This Gabriel García Márquez novel popularized magical realism.
This J.R.R. Tolkien trilogy features Frodo Baggins and the One Ring.
This Leo Tolstoy epic novel chronicles the lives of five families during the Napoleonic Wars.
